video.title: Data Structures - Intro to Computer Science - Harvard's CS50 (2018)
video.description:
Learn about data structures in the c programming language.

This course teaches the foundations of computer science. This video is lecture 4 of Harvard University's CS50 2018 course (part 5 since the lectures start at 0).

Check out our full CS50 playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbmGw5fN5BQlwuug-8bDmabi

🔗CS50 IDE (must have free edX account): https://cs50.io/

🔗Handout: https://cs50.harvard.edu/college/guide.pdf

🔗Notes: https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/notes/4/
🔗Problem Set: https://cs50.harvard.edu/x/2020/psets/4/
🔗Source Code: https://cdn.cs50.net/2019/fall/lectures/4/src4.zip

⭐️Contents⭐️
⌨️ (00:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:00:50) Week 3 Recap
⌨️ (00:05:55) memory.c
⌨️ (00:19:48) ddb50
⌨️ (00:21:40) Week 3 Recap, continued
⌨️ (00:31:07) struct.h
⌨️ (00:32:37) struct0.c
⌨️ (00:35:03) Linked Lists
⌨️ (00:45:22) typedef
⌨️ (00:50:23) Linked Lists on Stage
⌨️ (01:02:24) list0.c
⌨️ (01:08:44) list1.c
⌨️ (01:25:26) list2.c
⌨️ (01:40:21) Hash Tables
⌨️ (01:50:05) Trees
⌨️ (01:54:50) Tries

Lecture taught by David J. Malan. Thanks to Harvard's CS50 for giving us permission to post this lecture. Checkout their YouTube channel for more great lectures: https://www.youtube.com/cs50

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: 47Mortuus
topLevelComment.text:
"I want to store 500 ints - please give me room for 1500 - FoR PeRfOrMaNcE" ;)
Not only does it triple memory usage (in this case) or worse, it also relies on reading values from RAM which take houndreds of CPU clock cycles per value, which wouldn't be the case when accessing an array linearly (prefetching and cache line sizes i.e a CPU loads 64 bYtEs of contiguous memory each time it reads any value - linked lists additionally introduce cache misses and RAM bandwith waste).
Linked lists usecases are very limited, in addition to the provided reasoning being exceptionally misleading.

topLevelComment.author: Nan jayo
topLevelComment.text: What's the difference between a struct and a object?

replies.author: Devansh Tyagi
replies.text:
Generally speaking, objects bring the full object oriented functionality (methods, data, virtual functions, inheritance, etc, etc) whereas structs are just organized memory. Structs may or may not have support for methods / functions, but they generally won't support inheritance and other full OOP features.

Note that I said generally speaking ... individual languages are free to overload terminology however they want to.

Arrays have nothing to do with OO. Indeed, pretty much every language around support arrays. Arrays are just blocks of memory, generally containing a series of similar items, usually indexable somehow.

replies.author: K Downing
replies.text: It's about THE lowest of "high level" languages; being just above assembly in levels of abstraction.

replies.author: Zynade
replies.text:
@Clepsyd Nice, one correction though:
C is NOT a low-level language. Yes, C is definitely lower level than say Python. However, C is still considered a high-level language by definition.

replies.author: Clepsyd
replies.text:
A data structure is just the way you store and retrieve data within the memory.

Many kinds of data structures exist in different languages. This particular lesson is about the C language, which is a low level language, which means that as a programmer  you have to pay close attention to how you deal with memory. In other languages, similar or different types of data structures may be implemented, whether they're part of the language or an extra functionnality added to it via libraries.
To give you an example, Python is quite a high-level language that implements a built-in data structure called 'lists'. Lists in Python don't require you to worry about memory allocation, pointers etc., and provide you with tools (methods) to add, delete, sort or change their contents quite freely, at the cost of performance (the computer has to do the job you don't have to do by organising stuff in the memory).

But remember that's just one kind of data structure you can find in this language, which is itself just one language you can use to make your computer do things.
